             Review: Hanuman takes Thai dining upscale in Costa Mesa
            </span>
           </h1>
           <h2 class="subheadline">
            Critic Brad A. Johnson says the khao soi is the best of its genre in Orange County
           </h2>
          </div>
         </div>

          <div class="meta">
           <img alt="Author" class="avatar avatar-85 photo avatar-default coauthor-avatar" height="85" src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=85&d=mm&r=g" srcset="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=170&d=mm&r=g 2x" width="85">
            <div class="coauthor-avatar-container">
             <div class="byline">
              By
              <a class="author-name" href="https://www.ocregister.com/author/brad-johnson/" rel="author" title="Posts by Brad Johnson">
               Brad Johnson
              </a>
              | Orange County Register
             </div>
             <div class="time">
              PUBLISHED:
              <time datetime="2021-10-14 11:03:52">
               October 14, 2021 at 11:03 AM PDT
              </time>
             </div>

         <div class="article-body">
          <div class="body-copy">
           <div class="wp-remixd-voice-wrapper">
            <script async="" charset="utf-8" id="remixd-audio-player-script" src="https://tags.remixd.com/player/v5/index.js?cb=%%CACHEBUSTER%%" type="text/javascript">
            </script>
           </div>
           <p>
            The velvet banquettes, the custom wallpaper, the teak wood carvings and hand-stenciled cement floors, plus truly beautiful china and serving wares: Hanuman in Costa Mesa is easily the prettiest Thai restaurant in Orange County. The food, too, is beautiful. Every dish is a work of art. Fortunately, most of it is also delicious, even if some of it is extremely Americanized.
            <span class="Apple-converted-space">
            </span>
            <p>
             I could order the khao soi again and again with no need for anything else except a cold Lao beer.
            </p>

                <img class="lazyload size-article_inline" data-sizes="auto" data-src="https://wpdash.medianewsgroup.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/OCR-L-Hanuman-WBOX-1014-7.jpg?w=620" data-srcset="https://wpdash.medianewsgroup.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/OCR-L-Hanuman-WBOX-1014-7.jpg?w=620 620w,https://wpdash.medianewsgroup.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/OCR-L-Hanuman-WBOX-1014-7.jpg?w=780 780w,https://wpdash.medianewsgroup.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/OCR-L-Hanuman-WBOX-1014-7.jpg?w=810 810w,https://wpdash.medianewsgroup.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/OCR-L-Hanuman-WBOX-1014-7.jpg?w=1280 1280w,https://wpdash.medianewsgroup.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/OCR-L-Hanuman-WBOX-1014-7.jpg?w=1860 1860w"/>

             <div class="caption">
              <button class="caption-expand">
               Show Caption
              </button>

              <p>
               <a class="icon-enlarge" href="#">

               </a>
              </p>
             </div>
            </div>
            <p>
             It is a hearty one-dish meal, a creamy yellow curry with a surface speckled by droplets of orange chile oil and mounds of shaved red onion and fried shallots. A curious curve of chicken leg protrudes from the curry like the top of a submarine re-emerging from the depths of the bowl where soft egg noodles wriggle underneath. Despite a dangerous-looking dollop of red chile paste, the khao soi is not spicy enough. But that’s a recurring theme here. It is nonetheless the county’s best rendition of this northern Thai staple.
            </p>
            <p>
             So, too, the excellent “spicy” basil stir-fry called pad ga pow (the phonetic translation sometimes spelled as “ka pow” or “kra pao” in the English alphabet), which is made here the traditional Thai way with ground meat and served with a lacy fried egg perched atop the accompanying jasmine rice. If only it were indeed spicy.
            </p>
            <p>
             For dishes like the pad ga pow, the kitchen offers three levels of heat: mild, medium or spicy. The difference between these options is negligible. That said, servers are quick to offer a variety of fresh and dried chilies on the side.
             <span class="Apple-converted-space">
             </span>
            </p>
            <p>
             The kitchen excels at traditional noodles like pad Thai, pad kee mao (drunken noodles) and Thai boat noodles. And for people who don’t normally like boat noodles because of all that pork blood, try these, in which the blood and innards are micro-dosed, resulting in a welcoming, easy-to-eat soup filled with glass noodles, pork meatballs and crunchy things akin to Thai-style bacon bits.
             <span class="Apple-converted-space">
             </span>
            </p>

            <aside class="related right">
             <h2 class="widget-title">
              More from Brad A. Johnson
             </h2>

               </a>

            </aside>
            <p>
             I’m torn on the green curry. The beef that’s served with it is steakhouse-grade, cooked perfectly medium-rare. But the curry itself is too sweet and oddly riddled with a handful of edamame beans, which diminish rather than elevate this dish’s credibility.
             <span class="Apple-converted-space">
             </span>
            </p>
            <p>
             For reasons I cannot fathom, the papaya salad contains far more lettuce than actual papaya and no discernible spice or citrus. I wouldn’t say it’s the worst Thai papaya salad in the county, but it’s pretty close. Fortunately, duds like this are few and far between, even when the kitchen veers headfirst into fusion territory.
             <span class="Apple-converted-space">
             </span>
            </p>
            <p>
             There’s an excellent ceviche, served with rice crackers. While perfectly delicious, it feels more Polynesian tiki bar-ish, or even Mexican, than Thai. As I’m licking the bowl, I can’t help but think the hamachi could be even better if it leaned into the
             <a href="https://www.ocregister.com/2020/01/29/best-thing-i-ate-this-thai-shrimp-salad-is-a-game-changer/">
              Thai tradition of kung chae nampla
             </a>
             (often called naked shrimp), which is essentially a Thai ceviche made with freshly shelled raw shrimp tossed with kaffir lime juice, garlic and fistfuls of Thai chilies.
             <span class="Apple-converted-space">
             </span>
            </p>
            <p>
             There’s also an interesting lamb chop appetizer, which tastes of no specific cuisine or heritage but rather a mishmash of flavors that vaguely reference the ancient spice routes. Good, but not something I would order again in a Thai restaurant.
             <span class="Apple-converted-space">
             </span>
            </p>

             </div>
            </div>
            <p>
             When I look around the room, the dish I see most people enjoying is the fried chicken, which is one of those dishes that belongs to no one and to everyone at the same time. In this case, the recipe comes from Southern Thailand near the border with Malaysia, where the owners emigrated from when they came to the United States nearly 20 years ago as curious twentysomethings. But for its intensely dark and crispy skin and the sweet chile dipping sauce and sticky rice served alongside, the taste is not all that different from what you might already know and love. It’s impossible not to love good fried chicken.
             <span class="Apple-converted-space">
             </span>
            </p>
            <p>
             One of my favorite things about dining at Hanuman is the service, which is far more sophisticated than what Orange County’s best Thai restaurants typically deliver. And when I say that, I’m not referring to hospitality but rather to the structure and efficiency of the way everyone works. Servers input orders on iPads slung across their shoulders. Dishes are coursed and paced by the chefs. Tables are bussed constantly and meticulously. There is an orderliness and discipline not just in the dining room but even more so in the kitchen that suggests years of formal training in fancy, fine-dining restaurants.
             <span class="Apple-converted-space">
             </span>
            </p>
            <p>
             Hanuman doesn’t serve lunch. The restaurant opens at 3 p.m., and by 3:30 the dining room has already filled halfway. By 5 o’clock, there is a 30-minute wait. Come any later than that and you can expect to wait about an hour, especially on Fridays and Saturdays. Plan accordingly.
             <span class="Apple-converted-space">
             </span>
            </p>
            <h3>
             Hanuman
            </h3>
            <p>
             <strong>
              Where
             </strong>
             : 355 Bristol St., Costa Mesa
            </p>
            <p>
             <strong>
              When
             </strong>
             : Monday-Saturday, 3-10 p.m.
            </p>
            <p>
             <strong>
              Phone
             </strong>
             : 657-699-3123
            </p>
            <p>
             <strong>
              Online
             </strong>
             :
             <a href="http://hanumanthaieatery.com">
              hanumanthaieatery.com
             </a>
            </p>
           </p>

										dropdownToggle();
									}
								});
						});
